configure.p: The Correlation actor uses R to perform parametric and non-parametric tests of association between two input variables (e.g., two arrays of equal length). The actor outputs the level of association (r, rho, or tau, depending on the analysis) between the two variables, an estimate of the p-value (if possible), and n.

The actor uses R to perform a variance analysis and outputs a graphical representation of its calculations. The R application must be installed on the local system to use this actor. R is a language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. For more information about R, see http://www.r-project.org/.

By default, the actor performs a Pearson's correlation analysis; to specify another analysis type, connect a Constant actor to the actor's method port and enter another type of analysis (e.g., "spearmen" or "kendall").
The actor performs the analysis and saves the results to the Kepler working directory. To view the results, connect an ImageJ actor to the graphicsFileName output port.

property.name: port:association
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the calculated level of variable association.

property.name: port:graphicsFileName
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the generated graph of the results.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a copy of the text output that R generates. As the actor communicates with R to run the R function or script, the output port sends back the response (i.e., the values and statistical outputs).

property.name: port:Variable2
property.configure: An input port that accepts the second variable. The variable is specified as an array of values. The array length must match that of the array specified for Variable1.

property.name: port:Method
property.configure: The method used to perform the correlation analysis. The default method is Pearson. To change the method, connect a Constant actor and enter another type of analysis (e.g., "spearman" or "kendall").

property.name: port:p_value
property.configure: An output that broadcasts the p-value.

property.name: port:n
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the number of data pairs in the input.

property.name: port:Variable1
property.configure: An input port that accepts the first variable. The variable is specified as an array of values. The array length must match that of the array specified for Variable2.

property.name: prop:numXPixels
property.configure: The width of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:Rcwd
property.configure: The 'R' working directory (the home directory by default).

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: The expression that is evaluated to produce the output.

property.name: prop:displayGraphicsOutput
property.configure: Specify whether or not to create a graphics output port. By default, the actor will create a graphics output port.

property.name: prop:graphicsOutput
property.configure: Specify whether or not to create a graphics output port. By default, the actor will create a graphics output port.

property.name: prop:graphicsFormat
property.configure: The graphics output format. Currently the actor supports either *.pdf or *.png.

property.name: prop:numYPixels
property.configure: The height of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:save_nosave
property.configure: Specify whether or not to save the R workspace when R is closed; set to '--save' to retrieve the workspace later in a workflow in another R-actor.

property.name: expression
property.value:
if (any(ls() == "Method") == FALSE) {Method <- "pearson"}
Variable1 <- as.numeric(Variable1) Variable2 <- as.numeric(Variable2) plot(Variable1, Variable2)
final <- cor.test(Variable1, Variable2, method = Method)
association <- as.numeric(final$estimate) p_value <- final$p.value n <- length(Variable1)
